question.text: Which of the following is most suitable description for trachea?

options.text: Straight tube, extending upto the mid-thoracic cavity and divides at the level of 5<sup>th</sup> thoracic vertebra.
Straight tube, extending upto the mid-thoracic cavity and divides at the level of 3<sup>rd </sup>thoracic vertebra.
Straight tube, extending upto the neck and divides at the level of 5<sup>th</sup> cervical vertebra.
Curved tube, extending upto the mid-thoracic cavity and divides at the level of 5<sup>th</sup> thoracic vertebra.

solution.text:
Trachea : It is a straight tube that extends upto the mid-thoracic cavity and divides at the level of 5th thoracic vertebra into 2 branches: a right and left primary bronchi.

Branching in trachea leads to primary bronchi → secondary bronchi → tertiary bronchi and bronchioles → terminal bronchioles → alveoli (numerous very thin, irregular-walled and vascularised bag-like structures).

The tracheae, bronchi (primary, secondary and tertiary) and initial bronchioles are supported by incomplete cartilaginous rings.
